Params: As the dust from the collapse gradually settles, the imprisoned corpses finally regain their freedom, scattering under the winter sky.
From beneath the layers of rubble, a frail and elderly figure emerges.
He struggles to free himself from the weight of the corpses piling above him, managing to squeeze half his body out.
...Still trying to drag me down... Tch!
Bethe raises his head, looking toward the flat road ahead, only to be greeted by a long-awaited sword.
The young man steps on him, coldly pressing for information.
Before he can finish pretending ignorance, Bethe feels a sharp pain piercing his left collarbone.
I won't waste time on other questions. You're not going to tell the truth anyway, and I don't have the patience either.
Tell me, where is the commandant?
You bastard, arrrgh... How dare you treat an old man like this...!
Have you ever considered this question when you torture those children to death?
So, you went through all this trouble just to seek revenge for my little daughter?
I'm indeed grateful to Bella, and it pains me that I couldn't save her. However, if she chose not to mention you, I shouldn't act on something I have no right to know.
This is for those who lost their lives here, and for the children you might harm in the future.
As for the rest, I believe you're well aware.
Noan raises his leg and forcefully stomps down on his other collarbone.
Right, in your dreams! Will you let me go if I tell you? Even the replica Lithos sent is better than you... At least he would...
That's because you made "that me" forget what happened after the Cargo Crew's rebellion failed.
If there's anything that could alter my decision without me realizing it, this would be the only way.
Noan twists his wrist, driving the sword into Bethe's squirming hand at his side, letting the blade slice through half of his palm.
Screams of unrelenting agony burst forth from the old man's mouth once again, still unanswered.
Still trying to buy some time, huh? Are you so confident that he will come to your rescue?
Buy time from a rabid dog?
If you had approached me with a more "negotiable" stance from the beginning, I wouldn't have had to meet you this way.
Noan once again raises his leg, stepping on Bethe's right chest.
Even without any force exerted, the old man, who revels in punishing children, trembles like a leaf in the cold wind.
You traitor! Even Rachel was mistaken about you... The failure of the Cargo Crew's rebellion was a direct result of your final decision!
And here you are, harming their very benefactor! Without the weapons I supplied to the Cargo Crew, you wouldn't even have that sword in your hand!
Upon hearing these words, Noan's expression remains unchanged.
Where did those weapons you provided actually come from? And how many of them... were just cast-offs from the upper class?
You knew what Captain Rachel was preparing for, and you still introduced to Ashlar someone who could sell those military circular machines behind her back, didn't you?
Babylonia holds much more intel than the ground. It's just a matter of verifying the sources and adding some speculation to grasp the connection.
To Babylonia, you're just a handy soldier, nothing different from cargo or tools.
You may think you're clever... but regardless, you're just a sheepdog among the pack, ready to be replicated, mass-produced, and discarded at their whims!
Noan scoffs at the facts laid out by him.
Say what you will. I only care how the people I care about see me.
To put it in another way...
If you see me as a sheepdog, how dare you take the sheep away from me?
Bethe gasps for air, his body trembling from the waves of pain coursing through him.
Rabid dogs like the Cargo Crew will bite until their very last breath. Isn't that what you said?
Haha... Cargo Crew... Rachel used to tell me all the time...
That you were a good kid... Now I see, she was betrayed because she didn't know the real you...!
Captain Rachel had seen me do similar things when I was nine. She just didn't need to tell you about the real me.
Just because I've learned to restrain myself these years, it doesn't mean I can treat people like you the same.
Have you bought enough time? Will "that me" really come?
No matter what you become, you will always be a traitor!
I'll ask one last time: where is the commandant?
You should have ******* died in the snow alongside Rachel and those bastards of the Cargo Crew!
Noan, without uttering another word, steps down on Bethe's chest.
Immediately, the ribs near the abdomen emit faint cracking sounds, overwhelmed by his screams of agony.
Noan pauses briefly, granting Bethe a moment to catch his breath and speak, while also exerting control over his force to ensure he doesn't immediately end the man's life.
This is a "judgment" detached from the notions of right or wrong, witnessed by the remnants of countless deceased.
The executioner displays neither the pleasure of cruelty nor any mercy as he metes out violence with violence.
Only the Rev Blade is trembling slightly in the hand of its owner—
Beneath that tranquil expression as cold as a winter night lies Noan's soul, trembling from painstakingly suppressing the rage that threatens to consume him.
From the ribs, down to the shins, and further to the knees...
When all hope of escape is mercilessly ripped away from his aged body, Bethe finally capitulates amidst his own lugubrious screams.
The location... Arrgh... I'll tell you...
Shivering, he spits out the coordinates, a location situated a full 77 kilometers away.
You're hoping "that Noan" will come rushing to your rescue, but the commandant with him is this far away?
...I-it's true. If you don't believe me, take me with you...
The secret channel, after a long silence, finally transmits a familiar and urgent voice.
This location... It's close... The seaside lighthouse?
The human voice gets drowned out by a burst of static before being cut off completely.
No, it's not me. I didn't—
The roaring engine of the Rev Blade puts everything to silence.
That's all that needs to be said.
He gazes at the human's terminal in his hand, contemplating its destruction, but eventually turns it off and tosses it over, along with the firefly.
If "that Noan" has memories, he'll soon find this place.
Thank you for giving back the terminal.
After hearing Bethe and Noan's conversation through the comms, the young man's attitude finally starts to waver.
...Yet, he continues to assert that he hasn't placed his trust in anyone.
It wouldn't be surprising if either Babylonia or the Ascendants were to lie.
Lithos would often put on some realistic plays. No one can guarantee that Bethe isn't orchestrating something else with "the other me."
The young man's voice suddenly softens.
Lithos does have intentions to take away "the other me" and also forbids me from killing... him.
It took me a long while to finally find an opportunity to persuade Bethe to act on his own.
If what he says is true, that the "other me" is the real one, and only the original M.I.N.D. can be replicated.
Then his actions to restrict me make sense.
...The feeling of discord in my memories, perhaps it's due to this.
I still can't fully trust what you've said.
Who knows if these voices are orchestrated to stage this play?
Even upon realizing the truth, this person, burdened with too many lies, still stubbornly refuses to believe.
If one day... the memories I recover align with what you or "the other Noan" have said...
The young man leans against the wall, remaining silent for a long, long time.
No, apologizing won't make up for anything... I must do something.
In this moment, those unfamiliar, clouded eyes take on a striking resemblance to Noan's.
Until these matters are verified, I will continue to see both your words and Lithos' as lies.
He reverts back to his indifferent demeanor.
What exactly does Lithos want from you?
Some "bricks," to either toss at people or construct walls.
I've seen Lithos die in front of me twice now, and each Lithos is slightly different.
The current him just wants a bit of entertainment to kill the boredom and a tool that comes in handy.
You know this, and you still choose to help him?
He granted me the ability to resist the virus and the Red Tide, and access to the Ascendants' plan. We're simply using one another.
Better than being "the other me," always under someone's watch and restricted in everything.
As this is mentioned, a flash of resentment crosses the young man's eyes.
He's been in Babylonia for quite some time, right? Has he ever achieved anything?
The arrangements with Dark Aries indeed have flaws.
But that doesn't mean they've been sitting there and doing nothing.
It's just some more trouble. He's better off being killed here by me.
With the original one gone, there will be no more replicas created. It's better this way.
I don't need so many replicas of myself... "That Noan" would think the same.
With his head lowered, he mutters to himself amidst a whirlwind of thoughts and self-doubt.
How about coming back with me?
Add another one to your fancy prison? An upper-echelon like you surely can't understand how disgusting that is, can you?
...There are still some issues with my frame that only he can resolve.
But your memory isn't complete right now.
You'll eventually realize this path has strayed from your will.
I'll worry about that when the day comes. I still can't trust the words I hear here.
He stands up and pushes open the door of the cell.
The harsh winter sea wind lashes the lighthouse, its mournful wails echoing through the air.
Low-hanging, somber clouds sprawl across the sky, their presence dark and ominous.
Amidst the biting cold, a figure hurries up to the lookout platform on the outer edge of the lighthouse's peak.
Noan halts before this individual, so very similar to himself.
His gaze sweeps over those dim eyes and the wound on his chest, confirming that this frame is still under the control of the Ascendants.
The young man who has lost his name also lifts his gaze toward "the other him."
However, his gaze quickly shifts past him, landing on the nearby human commandant, ensuring the latter's safety.
This Noan is stating the harsh truth with his indifference—
Even caged, he still lives among those beyond his reach, living in his own "present."
Even caged, the path of the Transcendant remains unworthy of mention.
Why can you so firmly believe that your choice is the correct one?
Long concealed, the sludge that has accumulated in his heart finally breaks free from its confines in this very moment.
The nameless replica sneers, at the puppet whose every word and action is being watched.
The Rev Blade pierces through the air, its sound almost simultaneous with the scoffing laughter, as the Transcendant reaches Noan in the blink of an eye.
In this fleeting moment of blades clashing, Noan, ever vigilant, blocks the Transcendant's strike with the two swords at his side.
Why... why is a puppet living in a cage the real me?
Uttering this unbearable truth, he gradually increases the force exerted into his Rev Blade.
If you're so desperate to end the troubles caused by the replicas, why don't you just die here...!
The Punishing Virus carried by the Transcendant transforms into crimson electric currents, spreading uncontrollably with his every movement.
Corruption entwines, eroding the clean frame—as if determined to drag him down to hell.
Without the original, there will be no more replicas!
Lightning bursts forth from the clashing blades, emitting a dazzling light.
The two similar figures fight atop the lighthouse with nearly identical styles, their silhouettes blending seamlessly.
After a night of intense battles, Noan's movements have become sluggish.
As the power of the Transcendant is enhanced, he can wield this Rev Blade to strike heavier slashes even without the off-hand sword from the past.
The two Rev Blades briefly cross again, while Noan dodges relentlessly amidst the corruption and the overwhelming attacks.
—He can't make it if this drags on.
Sidestepping the lightning spray of the blade, Noan takes two swift steps on the railing before leaping from the height.
In a desperate move, the Rev Blade strikes the figure below, the engine roaring thunderously. However, in the very instant, he suddenly abandons all resistance.
Losing his target, the Transcendant stumbles sharply, and when he turns back, the long-prepared off-hand sword is descending from above!
The young man, covering his injured right eye, quickly retreats and looks up at Noan with his teeth gritted.
Despite his attempt to readjust and attack, his frame responds with unexpected sluggishness and stiffness.
What follows is a sudden rise in the concentration of the Punishing Virus in the air.
In the next second, countless crimson spikes burst forth from the Transcendant's sides, screaming as they launch attacks in all directions.
His vision, disrupted and distorted, becomes enveloped in red—a telltale sign that Lithos is nearby.
...It can't be. If he were nearby, he wouldn't just do this.
Caught off guard by the sudden turn of events, the young man involuntarily steps back, inching closer to the seaside railing.
Just two steps away from plunging into the sea, a pair of hands firmly grasp his collar.
Before he can make sense of what has happened, a greater pain suddenly pierces through—
The off-hand sword stabs into his eye socket, helping its master pull out the young man's struggling eyeball.
Covering the eye that constantly leaks vital fluid, the Transcendant lets out a short cry of agony amidst the intense pain.
Lucky me. It only takes one wound to find the "monitor" left by Lithos... although he may have left behind other things too.
—He is shocked to find that his vision, covered in red, is starting to recover.
This maneuver's classic Lithos, always keeping tabs on you.
Lay a finger on that watchful eye, and suddenly you're branded a rebel.
Next thing you know, he's pulling the strings, commandeering your frame.
With hands pierced by those wicked Punishing spikes, he clutches onto the poor young man who tries to step back.
Still not getting it? Who's the real puppet here?!
Can't handle Lithos? Step aside and let me handle it.
The young man's senses are still in disarray as he stares at his "self," murmuring.
Yeah, you've wandered off the path. It's time you got back in line.
The stray shadow chuckles at himself.
He leans in close to his "true self," whispering a sentence softly...
The overcast sky rumbles faintly, a chilly wind carrying the mocking curse into his ears.
Seizing the momentary doubt those words have brought, the "shadow" breaks loose from the grasp of his "other self" and plunges back into the deep sea below the lighthouse.
Without a second thought, Noan hops onto the railing, following his silhouette and leaping off the tower's peak!
Are you out of your mind?!
In a last-ditch effort, you manage to snag his injured hands just in time.
